subject: Politics
title: The Business Model Crisis
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Business Model Crisis usable.

hook.text: Quality journalism costs money. But nobody wants to pay for news. The business model that funded truth is dying.

buildup.text: Newspapers once thrived on classified ads and subscriptions. The internet destroyed both revenue streams.

discovery.text: Digital advertising goes mostly to Google and Meta. News organizations get the scraps despite creating the content.

twist.text: Paywalls work for elite outlets like the NYT. Most local and mid-sized papers can't convince enough people to pay.

climax.text: Nonprofit journalism, philanthropy, and public funding are growing alternatives. But they can't replace what was lost.

punchline.text: If nobody pays for truth, only propaganda will be free. Quality costs money.

quiz.question: Why is the traditional news business model collapsing?
options: Digital advertising revenue goes mostly to Google and Meta, not news organizations
People are reading more newspapers than ever
News organizations have no costs to cover
